items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS nears Jupiter flyby after archival data reveals early presence

featured_image.name: Water on interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS glows in ultraviolet light

items.description:
Scientists have confirmed that the interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS was captured in space-based observations nearly two months before its official discovery on July 1, 2025, underscoring questions about how automated detection systems process vast astronomical datasets. The revelation comes as the interstellar visitor approaches a close pass with Jupiter in mid-March that researchers say could expose new secrets about its composition and structure.

According to newly confirmed analyses, 3I/ATLAS appeared in data collected by NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) between May 7 and June 2, 2025—55 days before the ATLAS telescope in Chile flagged the object as a potential interstellar visitor. The comet remained effectively invisible in those earlier recordings until scientists revisited the data with updated parameters and image-stacking techniques, coadding more than 9,000 individual frames to reconstruct a faint but consistent signal matching the object's trajectory.[1][2][3]

items.title: Scientists engineer bacteria to produce molecules using light

featured_image.name: Light-Driven Method Boosts Eco-Friendly Biomanufacturing with ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign have engineered bacteria that can manufacture novel molecules when activated by light, marking what scientists describe as the first integration of light-driven enzymatic reactions into cellular metabolism. The proof-of-concept study, published this week in Nature Catalysis, could expand the range of compounds that can be sustainably produced through biomanufacturing.[1][2][3]

The technology works by equipping Escherichia coli bacteria with artificial photoenzymes—light-activated catalysts capable of performing chemical reactions that natural enzymes cannot achieve. When illuminated, these engineered bacteria can convert glucose into higher-value chemical products without requiring costly external materials.[4][1]

items.title: NASA confirms 3I/ATLAS was in its data months before discovery

featured_image.name: NASA’s TESS Captures First Images of Rare Interstellar Comet 3I/ATLAS

items.description:
Seven months after the discovery of interstellar object 3I/ATLAS, NASA has confirmed that the comet was captured in observational datasets dating back to May 2025—almost two months before astronomers identified it as a visitor from another star system. The revelation is prompting renewed scrutiny of planetary defense detection capabilities.

According to peer-reviewed research and NASA statements, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) recorded the comet nearly continuously from May 7 to June 2, 2025—55 days before its official discovery on July 1, 2025. The object was too faint to be detected in individual 200-second TESS exposures, and only became visible when researchers retroactively stacked thousands of images after learning where to look.[1][2][3][4]

"The mission's wide field of view previously happened to observe 3I/ATLAS in May 2025, almost two months before it was discovered," NASA stated in a January 27 blog post announcing new TESS observations of the comet. "Astronomers looking back at the TESS data were able to identify the faint comet by stacking multiple observations to track its movement."[5]

items.title: SpaceX seeks FCC approval for 1 million AI data center satellites

featured_image.name: Explainer-Why does Elon Musk want to put AI data centers in space?

items.description:
SpaceX submitted an unprecedented request to the Federal Communications Commission on Friday, seeking authorization to deploy up to one million satellites to create a network of orbiting data centers powered by artificial intelligence. The filing comes as reports emerged that SpaceX is in merger talks with Elon Musk's AI company xAI ahead of a planned initial public offering.

The dual developments signal an ambitious effort to combine Musk's space and artificial intelligence ventures into a unified entity capable of building computing infrastructure in orbit, potentially reshaping the future of AI development.

items.title: Scientists drill through Antarctica's 'Doomsday Glacier'

featured_image.name: ITGC Thwaites Glacier

items.description:
Researchers drilling through nearly 3,000 feet of ice have broken through to the ocean beneath Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier, marking a milestone in a high-stakes mission to understand one of the planet's most unstable ice masses.

A joint British and South Korean team punched through the ice on Thursday afternoon local time, according to PBS science correspondent Miles O'Brien, who is embedded with the expedition. After more than 21 hours of continuous drilling, instruments designed to measure temperature, salinity, and ocean currents were lowered into waters that scientists believe are eroding the glacier from below.[1][2]

items.title: Venezuela frees all known US detainees, announces amnesty law

featured_image.name: Venezuela announces amnesty bill that could lead to mass release ...

items.description:
Venezuela's interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, announced Friday a general amnesty law covering political prisoners detained since 1999, a measure that could benefit hundreds of detainees as the South American nation moves to satisfy U.S. demands nearly a month after Nicolás Maduro's capture by American forces.

The announcement, made during an event at the Supreme Court of Justice in Caracas, comes as the U.S. Embassy confirmed it had secured the release of all known American citizens detained in Venezuela.[1][2]

items.title: Carlyle in talks with UAE investors over Lukoil asset deal

featured_image.name: Exclusive: Carlyle in talks with potential UAE partners on Lukoil assets, sources say

items.description:
Carlyle Group has begun exploratory talks with Abu Dhabi investors about bringing in partners should its preliminary agreement to acquire Russian oil producer Lukoil's international assets proceed, according to Reuters, which cited three sources with knowledge of the process.[1][2]

The discussions come just one day after Carlyle and Lukoil announced the provisional deal on Thursday, which would transfer a sweeping portfolio of oilfields in Iraq and refineries in Eastern Europe to the U.S. private equity firm, pending approval from U.S. sanctions authorities.[3][4]

items.title: Top AI models score below 40% on new expert-level benchmark

featured_image.name: UK Business And Economy 2026

items.description:
A new benchmark designed to push the limits of artificial intelligence has been formally published in the journal Nature, revealing that even the most advanced AI systems score below 40% on questions that probe the frontier of human knowledge.

"Humanity's Last Exam" comprises 2,500 expert-level questions spanning more than 100 academic subfields, from interpreting ancient Palmyrene script on Roman tombstones to analyzing hummingbird skeletal structures. The benchmark represents a global collaboration of nearly 1,000 professors and researchers from over 500 institutions across 50 countries, including contributors from KAIST and Yonsei University in South Korea.[1][2]

items.title: Mexico warns of humanitarian crisis after Trump tariffs on Cuba oil

featured_image.name: Mexico to seek diplomatic solution after US threatens Cuba oil tariffs

items.description:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum warned Friday that US tariffs targeting countries that supply oil to Cuba could trigger a "far-reaching humanitarian crisis," as she announced her government would pursue diplomatic channels while seeking alternatives to assist the Caribbean island.

The announcement came one day after President Donald Trump signed an executive order authorizing tariffs on goods from any nation that directly or indirectly provides oil to Cuba, declaring the island "an unusual and extraordinary threat" to US national security. The decree did not specify tariff rates or which countries would be affected.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Bomb cyclone targets Southeast as Australia's record heat persists

featured_image.name: Severe weather brings heavy snow and ice across the U.S.

items.description:
As the United States reels from its deadliest winter storm in years, with at least 117 deaths confirmed and another bomb cyclone bearing down on the East Coast, Australia is simultaneously enduring its most severe heatwave since the 2019-20 Black Summer. Scientists say both events bear the unmistakable fingerprint of a warming planet.

Winter Storm Fern, which swept across the nation from January 23-26, brought catastrophic ice and snow from Northern Mexico to New England, causing over a million power outages and preliminary damage estimates exceeding $1 billion. Meanwhile, southeastern Australia has recorded temperatures approaching 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit), setting all-time records across multiple states.[1][2][3]

items.title: Bob Iger plans early exit as Disney board nears new CEO decision

featured_image.name: Disney CEO Bob Iger confirms he will step down at end of ...

items.description:
Bob Iger has informed associates he intends to step down as chief executive of the Walt Disney Company before his contract expires at the end of 2026, according to The Wall Street Journal. The entertainment giant's board of directors is scheduled to convene next week at Disney's headquarters in Burbank, California, where they are expected to select Iger's successor.[1][2][3]

The announcement signals a turning point in a succession process that has shadowed one of Hollywood's most influential executives. For Disney, the stakes are especially high after the company's 2020 leadership transition ended with the dismissal of Bob Chapek and the forced return of the 74-year-old Iger.[4][5]

items.title: SpaceX earned $8 billion profit in 2025, sources say

featured_image.name: Elon Musk Relocates SpaceX and X Headquarters | Brimco

items.description:
SpaceX generated approximately $8 billion in profit on revenue of $15 billion to $16 billion last year, according to a Reuters exclusive published Thursday, offering a rare glimpse into the financial performance of Elon Musk's aerospace company as it prepares for what could be the largest initial public offering in history.[1][2][3]

The profit figure represents earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA), a key measure of operational performance. Musk's satellite internet service Starlink drives the company's finances, accounting for 50 to 80 percent of total revenue, according to people familiar with the company's results.[4][3]

items.title: Gemini telescope reveals comet ATLAS crumbling after solar pass

featured_image.name: Comet C/2025 K1 (ATLAS) crumbles apart in stunning new ...

items.description:
Astronomers this week released new images documenting two distinct celestial objects bearing the ATLAS name: one a solar system comet that fragmented after its close solar approach, and the other an interstellar visitor that continues to puzzle scientists with its unusual jet structures and delayed detection in archival data.

The Gemini North telescope in Hawaii captured high-resolution footage of Comet C/2025 K1 (ATLAS) breaking apart, with images released Thursday showing the comet's nucleus splintering into multiple fragments following its closest approach to the Sun on October 8, 2025. Meanwhile, NASA confirmed that the interstellar object 3I/ATLAS had been present in archived TESS satellite data from May 2025—nearly two months before its official discovery on July 1, 2025.[1][2]

items.title: Oil prices ease as Trump signals openness to Iran talks

featured_image.name: Oil prices surge 3% to five-month high on worries US could ...

items.description:
Crude oil prices retreated from multi-month highs on Friday after President Donald Trump signaled he was open to talks with Iran over its nuclear program, tempering fears of an imminent military strike that had driven a sharp rally earlier in the week.

Brent crude fell nearly 1% on Friday, pulling back from the $70 level it had breached the day before for the first time since July, according to CNBC. West Texas Intermediate also declined more than 1%, dropping from the four-month highs reached Thursday.[1][2]

"President Trump's readiness to consider diplomacy with Iran appears to make a U.S. military action less probable than it was yesterday," said Tamas Varga, an analyst at PVM Oil Associates.[2]

items.title: Putin envoy to meet Trump officials in Miami Saturday

featured_image.name: Putin envoy Dmitriev to travel to Miami, meet members of ...

items.description:
Kirill Dmitriev, Russian President Vladimir Putin's special envoy, is scheduled to travel to Miami on Saturday for meetings with members of the Trump administration, according to two sources familiar with the plans, Reuters reported on Thursday.[1][2][3]

The visit marks the latest in a series of diplomatic engagements between Moscow and Washington as the two sides work toward a resolution to the war in Ukraine. Dmitriev, who heads the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), has emerged as a central figure in the Trump administration's efforts to broker peace between Russia and Ukraine.

items.title: New electrode converts exhaust CO2 into formic acid in one step

featured_image.name: New three-layer electrode converts exhaust CO2 into formic acid

items.description:
Researchers in South Korea have developed a new electrode capable of capturing carbon dioxide directly from exhaust gases and converting it into formic acid in a single step, an advancement that could simplify industrial carbon recycling.

The study, published January 21 in ACS Energy Letters and selected as an official press release by the American Chemical Society, introduces a three-layer electrode design that functions under realistic conditions rather than requiring purified carbon dioxide.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump's Greenland threats halt US-Danish climate research

featured_image.name: Trump's Greenland Threats Put Crucial Climate Change ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump's escalating pressure on Greenland has begun to chill scientific ties between American and Greenlandic researchers, with at least one climate program halted and future collaborations cast into uncertainty. The diplomatic strain comes just days after the United States officially exited the Paris Agreement, further isolating the country from global climate efforts.

Ross Virginia, a professor emeritus of environmental studies at Dartmouth College, said a climate program he ran with Greenlandic colleagues was halted by "mutual agreement" due to the tensions, according to Bloomberg News. "Direct cooperation is paused while we determine what a future vision for collaborative science diplomacy — particularly involving education and younger students — could look like," he said.[1][2][3]

Another US scientist, speaking anonymously for fear of jeopardizing relationships, said some research partnerships had been affected by the political climate.[3][1]

items.title: Zelensky backs energy truce, says Ukraine will halt strikes if Russia reciprocates

featured_image.name: Zelenskiy says Russia seems more inclined now to a ceasefire ...

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky endorsed a U.S.-proposed pause on strikes targeting energy infrastructure on Friday, pledging that Kyiv would halt attacks on Russian energy facilities if Moscow reciprocates—though he emphasized that no formal agreement exists between the two nations.

"If Russia does not strike our energy infrastructure—generation facilities or any other energy assets—we will not strike theirs," Zelensky told reporters on January 30, characterizing the arrangement as "an opportunity, not an agreement."[1][2][3]

The development follows President Donald Trump's announcement Thursday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had agreed to suspend attacks on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities for one week amid extreme cold weather. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed Friday that Trump "did indeed make a personal request to President Putin to refrain from striking Kyiv for a week until February 1 in order to create favorable conditions for negotiations."[4][5][1]

items.title: NASA probe data reveals origins of solar wind heating

featured_image.name: Durable Parker Solar Probe going strong after first five years

items.description:
Using measurements from NASA's Parker Solar Probe during its record-breaking closest approach to the sun, scientists have mapped the dynamic "shell" of hot gas where the solar wind is born, shedding new light on one of the most enduring mysteries in heliophysics.

The research, led by University of Arizona associate professor Kristopher Klein and published this week in Geophysical Research Letters, offers the first detailed analysis of how energy moves through the sun's outer atmosphere at distances never before measured, with implications for predicting space weather events that affect Earth's satellites, communications systems, and power grids.[1][2][3]

items.title: Satellite images show Iran building roofs over bombed nuclear sites

featured_image.name: Satellite photos show activity at Iran nuclear sites as ...

items.description:
New satellite imagery reveals Iran is placing roofs over two nuclear facilities bombed by Israel and the United States last year, raising concerns that Tehran is attempting to shield salvage operations from outside observation as the regime continues to block international inspectors from the sites.

Images from Planet Labs PBC show that Iran completed construction of roofs over damaged buildings at its Natanz and Isfahan nuclear facilities in late December 2025 and early January 2026, according to an Associated Press report published Thursday. The activity marks the first major construction visible by satellite at any of Iran's stricken nuclear sites since Israel's 12-day war with the Islamic Republic in June 2025.[1][2]
